Line 29: Line 29:
==Early life==
==Early life==
â
Davis is the eldest child of [[Korean War]] veteran Joseph Davis and hospital worker Virginia Davis.<ref name="smn310891"/><ref name="smn240889"/> The couple divorced when Davis was very young,<ref name="smn240889"/> and Davis grew up with four siblings in the predominantly black, middle-class neighborhood of Cloverdale, Savannah.<ref name="smn240889">{{Cite news|last=Smith|first=Derek|title=Neighbors say suspect not the man they knew|url=http://multimedia.savannahnow.com/media/DavisMcPhail/1989/198908AUG24NEIGHBORSREACT.pdf|newspaper=Savannah Morning News|date=August 24, 1989}}</ref> He attended [[Windsor Forest High School]], school officials said little about Davis, but a former teacher said he was anything but a good student. "He was a dumb kid and a worse student said the teacher."<ref name="smn240889"/> He dropped out in his junior year so he could drive his disabled younger sister to her rehabilitation.<ref name="smn310891"/> Davis obtained his high-school equivalency diploma from Richard Arnold Education Center in 1987. A teacher noted that he attended school regularly but seemed to lack discipline.<ref name="smn310891">{{Cite news|last=Fishman|first=Jane|title=Davises recall the kindness of defendant|url=http://multimedia.savannahnow.com/media/DavisMcPhail/1991/08311991Davissidebar1.pdf|newspaper=Savannah Morning News|date=August 31, 1991|page=1A}}</ref> Davis' nickname at the time was "Rah," or "Rough as Hell" , but neighbors reported that it did not reflect his behavior; they described him as a "straight up fella" who acted as a big brother to local children.<ref name="smn240889"/> In July 1988, Davis pled guilty to carrying a concealed weapon; he was fined $250 as part of a plea agreement in which a charge of possession of a gun with altered serial numbers was dropped.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Smith|first=Derek|title=Officers link suspect to another shooting|url=http://multimedia.savannahnow.com/media/DavisMcPhail/1989/198908AUG21SUSPECT%28EP%29.pdf|accessdate=sep210889|newspaper=Savannah Evening Press|date= 21 August1989|page=1}}</ref>
+
Davis is the eldest child of [[Korean War]] veteran Joseph Davis and hospital worker Virginia Davis.<ref name="smn310891"/><ref name="smn240889"/> The couple divorced when Davis was very young,<ref name="smn240889"/> and Davis grew up with four siblings in the predominantly black, middle-class neighborhood of Cloverdale, Savannah.<ref name="smn240889">{{Cite news|last=Smith|first=Derek|title=Neighbors say suspect not the man they knew|url=http://multimedia.savannahnow.com/media/DavisMcPhail/1989/198908AUG24NEIGHBORSREACT.pdf|newspaper=Savannah Morning News|date=August 24, 1989}}</ref> He attended [[Windsor Forest High School]], where one teacher described him as a poor student.<ref name="smn240889"/> He dropped out in his junior year so he could drive his disabled younger sister to her rehabilitation.<ref name="smn310891"/> Davis obtained his high-school equivalency diploma from Richard Arnold Education Center in 1987. A teacher noted that he attended school regularly but seemed to lack discipline.<ref name="smn310891">{{Cite news|last=Fishman|first=Jane|title=Davises recall the kindness of defendant|url=http://multimedia.savannahnow.com/media/DavisMcPhail/1991/08311991Davissidebar1.pdf|newspaper=Savannah Morning News|date=August 31, 1991|page=1A}}</ref> Davis' nickname at the time was "Rah," or "Rough as Hell" , but neighbors reported that it did not reflect his behavior; they described him as a "straight up fella" who acted as a big brother to local children.<ref name="smn240889"/> In July 1988, Davis pled guilty to carrying a concealed weapon; he was fined $250 as part of a plea agreement in which a charge of possession of a gun with altered serial numbers was dropped.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Smith|first=Derek|title=Officers link suspect to another shooting|url=http://multimedia.savannahnow.com/media/DavisMcPhail/1989/198908AUG21SUSPECT%28EP%29.pdf|accessdate=sep210889|newspaper=Savannah Evening Press|date= 21 August1989|page=1}}</ref>
In August 1988, Davis began work as a drill technician at a plant manufacturing railroad crossing gates. His boss reported that Davis was a likable and good worker who appeared to have positive life goals. However, his job attendance was poor, and by Christmas 1988 he stopped coming to work.<ref name="smn310891"/> Davis returned to the job twice in the following months, but neither time remained for long.<ref name="smn310891"/>
In August 1988, Davis began work as a drill technician at a plant manufacturing railroad crossing gates. His boss reported that Davis was a likable and good worker who appeared to have positive life goals. However, his job attendance was poor, and by Christmas 1988 he stopped coming to work.<ref name="smn310891"/> Davis returned to the job twice in the following months, but neither time remained for long.<ref name="smn310891"/>
